text: Also, Ohad offered to help  shape our ask over the next few days

elements.text: Also, Ohad offered to help  shape our ask over the next few days

text:
<@U01RV12B4A1> <@U0273KZ3668> Just picked Ohad’s brain to figure out the requirements of a good ask. He came up with the following points (more or less in order of importance):

1 The ask needs to have serious *impact* for the future of the company
    a. motivation
    b. outcomes
2 It needs to be honest and you have to show your *weaknesses*
    a. No sugar coating
    b. worst thing is those asks that are hidden self-compliments
3 It needs to be *specific* and *measurable* i.e. quantifiable (for instance, not _I need leads_ but _I need 3 leads)_
4 It needs to have a clear *owner* i.e. team member who is responsible to follow through

text:
<https://www.newyorker.com/culture/cultural-comment/slack-is-the-right-tool-for-the-wrong-way-to-work>

<@U0273KZ3668> This article frames the problem that you describe very well.

My idea would be to have *machine curation*, but the paradox is that in order to be able to do that we need less *human curation* to acquire the necessary data

attachments.title: Slack Is the Right Tool for the Wrong Way to Work
attachments.text: If Slack, which improves a fundamentally flawed approach to collaboration, is worth tens of billions of dollars, imagine the value in fixing the underlying problems.

text: <@U0273KZ3668> The ideal is that Lefthoek would actually curate the chat for you. In other words, select and redirect the contextually relevant info from the channels to you. Too much self-censorship and pre-curation/organization actually reduces the amount of info that could and maybe is relevant for someone. Simply because we don’t always know what is interesting to someone else or ourselves (currently and in the future)

text: <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mad_Libs>

attachments.title: Mad Libs
attachments.text:
Mad Libs is a phrasal template word game created by Leonard Stern and Roger Price. It consists of one player prompting others for a list of words to substitute for blanks in a story before reading aloud. The game is frequently played as a party game or as a pastime.
The game was invented in the United States, and more than 110 million copies of Mad Libs books have been sold since the series was first published in 1958.
